image.altText: A man, whose faces is obsucred, walks around a concrete area surrounded by high metal fenced walls.

items.synopsis: Adrian's been held for years in solitary confinement without a release date, living with an intellectual disability and chromosomal disorder. The public has never seen how he lives until now.

title.children: 'Get me out of here': Adrian's been pacing this caged area for more than a decade

image.altText: A large group of protesters posing with their signs, outside on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: A Greens senator and an independent are hoping to urgently close a legal loophole that allows fracking corporations "a license to drill without regard for rivers".

title.children: 'Water is our life': Federal bill introduced to close fracking loophole

image.altText: A group of Middle Eastern people stand in a car park next to a gated tin shed on sunny day

items.synopsis: What do you want to know about the Israel-Gaza war? Our global affairs correspondent John Lyons has been reporting from Israel along with the ABC team and is ready to answer your questions from 7:30pm AEDT. Follow live.

title.children: Ask our correspondent John Lyons your questions on the Israel-Gaza war

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Hey John. 
How scared are you currently from where your situated and are other people around you also feeling very scared/threated  - Peter. Peter, I think there is fear on both the Israeli and Palestinian sides. Everybody knows that a war can have tragic and unpredictable consequences. As for journalists, we know there’s a level of risk but we try to mitigate that risk wherever possible. As I said in an earlier post, while we’ve been doing this live blog a siren went off here in Ashdod which means we should go to a shelter. The thing you have to keep in mind in Ashdod is that you don’t have much time as it’s close to the Gaza border. Ashkelon is even closer. As soon as it went off I bolted for the stairwell, to get away from windows. In there I head two or three huge explosions – that could have been the missiles hitting or Israel’s Iron Dome system shooting down the incoming missiles. My point is that if you observe protocol – head quickly for the stairwells, etc – then you minimise your chance of something happening. That said, too many journalists are killed covering wars.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How are you feeling right now?

children.content:
Hey John. 
How scared are you currently from where your situated and are other people around you also feeling very scared/threated
Peter, I think there is fear on both the Israeli and Palestinian sides. Everybody knows that a war can have tragic and unpredictable consequences.
As for journalists, we know there’s a level of risk but we try to mitigate that risk wherever possible.

As I said in an earlier post, while we’ve been doing this live blog a siren went off here in Ashdod which means we should go to a shelter. The thing you have to keep in mind in Ashdod is that you don’t have much time as it’s close to the Gaza border. Ashkelon is even closer.

As soon as it went off I bolted for the stairwell, to get away from windows. In there I head two or three huge explosions – that could have been the missiles hitting or Israel’s Iron Dome system shooting down the incoming missiles.
My point is that if you observe protocol – head quickly for the stairwells, etc – then you minimise your chance of something happening. That said, too many journalists are killed covering wars.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Could this war result in the final defeat for the Palestinians and the end of their cause and existence as a people? (Other than Arab Israelis?)  - SR. I don’t think Hamas’ atrocities in southern Israel, and any possible defeat in Gaza, will spell the end for the Palestinians. Interestingly, Xi Jinping has come out in recent days supporting the Palestinians. Obviously he may be doing this because the United States is supporting “the other side”, but if Beijing decides to take up the cause of the Palestinians it will give it a huge new momentum.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Could this war result in the final defeat for Palestinians?

children.content: Could this war result in the final defeat for the Palestinians and the end of their cause and existence as a people? (Other than Arab Israelis?)
I don’t think Hamas’ atrocities in southern Israel, and any possible defeat in Gaza, will spell the end for the Palestinians.
Interestingly, Xi Jinping has come out in recent days supporting the Palestinians.
Obviously he may be doing this because the United States is supporting “the other side”, but if Beijing decides to take up the cause of the Palestinians it will give it a huge new momentum.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If reporters aren’t allowed into Gaza then what’s the risk for the reporters in Gaza not just from missile strikes but from Hamas reprisals/repression of media? - Jenson. Jenson, everyone in Gaza is in danger when an army as strong and big as the Israeli army is dropping bombs and launching a ground war (if that happens.) Gaza’s journalists are among the bravest in the world. Many of them are continuing to try to report as they are trying to get their own families to safety. And they are also courageous in the sense that they often report under the intimidation of Hamas.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What risks are Gaza's reporters facing?

children.content: If reporters aren’t allowed into Gaza then what’s the risk for the reporters in Gaza not just from missile strikes but from Hamas reprisals/repression of media?
Jenson, everyone in Gaza is in danger when an army as strong and big as the Israeli army is dropping bombs and launching a ground war (if that happens.)
Gaza’s journalists are among the bravest in the world. Many of them are continuing to try to report as they are trying to get their own families to safety.
And they are also courageous in the sense that they often report under the intimidation of Hamas.
